required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study to Assess the Efficacy of Early Physical Therapy Intervention Following a Modified Unilateral Neck Dissection for Treatment of Head and Neck Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Study to Assess the Efficacy of Early Physical Therapy Intervention on Upper Quarter Strength and Mobility, and Reported Upper Extremity Disability and Quality of Life Measures Following a Modified Unilateral Neck Dissection for Treatment of Head and Neck Cancer

brief_summary.textblock: This study will determine whether patients who receive regular physical therapy immediately following a modified neck dissection surgery will report decreased shoulder disability, decreased pain, improved or maintained shoulder range of motion and strength, and improved quality of life than those who receive only home instruction.

primary_outcome.measure: Disability of the Arm Shoulder and Hand
primary_outcome.description: A standardized outcome tool which will be used to measure change in the level of disability related to involvement of the upper extremity at 12, 24, and 36 weeks compared to baseline.

other_outcome.measure: Strength, range of motion of the neck and shoulder
other_outcome.description: Measurements of shoulder range of motion and strength, cervical range of motion

clinical_study.condition: Shoulder Weakness Following Neck Dissection Surgery

arm_group.description: Physical therapy intervention provided for first 12 weeks following surgery.

intervention.description: Exercises addressing cervical range of motion, shoulder range of motion and strengthening and scapular stabilization.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adults age 18-85, able to give informed consent
- Subject has provided written informed consent
- Received Modified Unilateral Neck Dissection with sparing of the SAN
- Not currently using transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) as a pain relieving modality
- Not currently receiving acupuncture as a pain relieving modality
- Able to participate with treatment group protocol including physical therapy appointment every other week
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of prior shoulder injury or surgery including rotator cuff repair or total shoulder arthroplasty.
- History of CVA with hemi paresis
- Bilateral neck dissection
- Known severed SAN

responsible_party.investigator_title: Physical Therapist, Orthopedic Clinical Specialist, Primary Investigator

clinical_study.keyword: Spinal Accessory Nerve Palsy, Cranial Nerve XI, shoulder weakness, neck stiffness, head and neck cancer, neck dissection
